text: <@U01UYA5NHD2> involving the whole team is really key. we have an asana project that anyone can add ideas to throughout the year, and then we evaluate those when planning. during planning we like to fly everyone in for an in-person meetup and split off in pairs to generate ideas. then we come together and discuss the ideas everyone came up with. this helps to get fresh ideas and also helps the team to better understand the content strategy overall.

text:
:wave: Would love some insight on *content briefs.* We use really detailed briefs with quality checks, helpful instructions etc.

But our brief template has become a somewhat heavy document (8 pages) and I wonder if there’s a way to make it more user-friendly, especially for the writer.

I wanted to ask how you deal with super detailed briefs so that all the info and instructions are there, it includes checklists to help standardise the process and keep the quality up, but without it being overwhelming for the writers? 

Here’s <https://www.loom.com/share/2bb4a202e07e40d88866f6f267d16236|a peek into our briefs> ( it’s a loom video, please speed me up 2x) and some improvements I’m thinking of:
• get the checklists for editor and PM into our project management system (ClickUp) 
• move the “Resources/About the client” section into our project management system (ClickUp)
Is it just a formatting issue or do you have other useful tips?
Thanks a lot and excited to hear from you :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
Hi Leanka, the process looks neat but my first question would be: do you need to include checklists for all the roles in the brief?

I assume that strategists, editors, and project managers are in-house, so they should know/always use the checklists either way (i.e. maybe they should be stored elsewhere?).

A less overwhelming brief for a writer would involve all the info they need to deliver what you're looking for -- nothing more, nothing less. And we're getting good results with briefs outlining: the general idea for a post, target audience, search intent, suggested headlines, internal linking opportunities, competing articles to beat, keywords to focus on. And that's all our writers seem to need.

EDIT: oh, and we give each new writer an access to our styleguide so they know what tone we're looking for.

text:
I love the detail on this! Avoiding making simple errors is definitely the one :raised_hands:

Loads of this, specifically checklists could be turned into evergreen documentation to reduce bulk, you can also create clearer reusable templates using Notion.

If you haven't heard of notion.so it's an extremely powerful organisational tool, free to use for up to 5 people. Me and most of my clients run our businesses with it. It has a little learning curve, but once you're over that, the sky is the limit. :ringed_planet:

We have brand guidelines, tone of voice, guidance, documentation and much more. I'd be lost without it.

You can also create public briefs if you write for clients. They can fill it out on their own or with your supervision on Zoom.

This will allow you to create much neater reusable templates and persistent documentation that everyone has access to.

Secondly, you could break this down. Not everyone needs to see every part of this document to get the job done.

You can create a project with different stages and subpages for each step.

So you seem to have this process:

Strategy -> Checklist -> SEO -> Content & Copywriting

Break down into 4 processes with 1 clear page for each.

Let me know if this helps.

text:
We meet every month (easier for a small team) where we review how past content is doing (last 5-12 months), plan for the next month's content, and even discuss any long-term ideas or strategies we want to pay attention to. These are usually the things we discuss:
• What types of new content do we need (blog posts, product/feature pages, landing pages, gated content, etc.)
• Any new keywords (or variations) we want to target
• How has our recent content been doing — what articles are viewers engaging with the most, what keywords are getting traction, and so on
• What might other departments need from us (sales enablement and customer support content)
• Where can we improve our existing content — here, we look at content refreshes and repurposing old content that isn’t doing much for us.

What might other departments need from us (sales enablement and customer support content)

text:
Hey all, any fellow freelancers who've started working with a client that's already engaged an SEO agency?

I'm working with a new company that I'm very excited to be working with, where I'm tasked with doing the strategy as well as some of the content writing. I'm supposed to also manage the SEO agency, who do 2 articles per month. As is often the case, the articles they create are generic "5 ways to do X" type blog posts which I'm not sure what to do with and aren't really aligned with the type of content we want to create.

Should I ask the client to renegotiate the contract with the agency so they don't waste efforts producing content, or do the best I can with the situation and try to coach/edit their articles as best I can? Curious to hear what others have done in this situation. Thanks!

text:
Tactical question: Can you use them as drafts to create something better?

Bigger (more important) question: How did they arrive at hiring this agency? What were the expectations then and how did whoever hired them get buy in to do so?

text:
I could, but I feel I'll spend more time rewriting the articles when I should be focused on creating more relevant, BOFU content (theirs is very TOFU).

And good question. I didn't ask this exact question so I will do on our next call.

text: As an SEO consultant who often gets brought in and ends up managing an agency in that same setup -- you could also consider it this way: if the client asked you to manage the agency... confirm with the client they're ok if you change the direction/output of that agency to align more strategically with what you're doing. And if they're ok with it, give the agency guidance on what you're looking for/want, what would add value and align to broader strategy... that way you get to leverage their resources to empower your own objectives and shows the client that you're keen to maximize resources at your disposal to help them grow. Also can check with the agency on why they're creating those pieces and evaluate if it makes sense to keep doing so or if it serves some purpose you may not be aware of. Think of them as a resource rather than an obstacle. And if after some trying the agency still just don't seem like a good fit - communicate it to the client that you believe there are better alternative options and make a suggestion.

And if they're ok with it, give the agency guidance on what you're looking for/want, what would add value and align to broader strategy... that way you get to leverage their resources to empower your own objectives and shows the client that you're keen to maximize resources at your disposal to help them grow. Also can check with the agency on why they're creating those pieces and evaluate if it makes sense to keep doing so or if it serves some purpose you may not be aware of. text:
Oh wow, thank you<@U02FV1XHS2C> :fire: This is better than I could have imagined!

This: _“Not everyone needs to see every part of this document to get the job done.”_ will become the mantra when improving our briefs.

Also very much along the lines of what <@U01A827PTTM> suggested, thank you!

We work in ClickUp, and are transitioning to make that our only source of truth bit by bit, so I’ll see if I can transport your suggestion from notion over there :crossed_fingers:

I had a quick check-in with our strategists, and they mentioned they’d appreciate it not having to switch between the document and another space when creating the brief, so I will also keep that in mind.

Love the idea of different views of the same brief depending on each role.

I feel really inspired - thank you SO much!

Will keep you updated on how I go along :slightly_smiling_face:

text: Is it the SEO agency's job to prepare/create the topics? Are they building out these types of articles based on keywords and specific topics they want to hit? There is a time and place for a "5 ways to do X" kind of article, but if it is only content for content's sake - I would have a conversation with the SEO agency. If they have a data-backed reason for the articles they are sending you, then let them do their thing. If you have an inkling that it's just random content because they are contractually obligated to send it - there is absolutely nothing wrong with asking questions about the topics. Shoot, I've even SUPPLIED topics to the SEO agency that I've worked with. You are paying them. But, I have a problem of "staying in my lane" when it comes to SEO. I have a SEO background and have switched primarily to content writing...but whenever I've worked with garbage SEO agencies (they DO exit), it gets my hackles up and I try not to ruffle any feathers by asking "what would you say, you do here?" to the hired agency...

text: No problems. I actually started in ClickUp and found it far too limiting. The time tracker is cool but I just use a free Pomodoro timer for that. Most of my clients are on fixed price packages. I'd prefer to focus on their work than tracking time. If they don't trust me then they aren't a good fit.

text:
<@U02CVNB3X1T> what do you mean exactly by "data-backed reason" -- do you mean like keyword volume and competition? The problem is that we are starting content from the ground up, and I believe we are better off focusing on sales and customer-focused questions (BOFU) and only then doing TOFU. The agency can only really do TOFU, so that's why I'm trying to figure out how they fit in...

Totally agree with you on not being afraid to ask questions!

text: <@U01MW6DPU72> Yes, that's what I mean with "data-backed." If it is a new site, then it should be more laser-focused on keyword gap analysis and topics/keyword clusters that closely align with your goals/target. But if you are only starting content, don't you think you need a mix of TOFU and BOFU - shoot even throw in some MOFU!! While 2 blogs a month is great, it really isn't going to set you back if you only have TOFU. IMO you do need a mix of content, but I also agree think that you need to be satisfied with the content they are providing you.  (so many acronyms here. All the acronyms).

text:
<@U02E91P5NTH> I agree that removing the parts that aren't relevant for the writer would make it easier and help them focus on what matters. Are these in-house or freelance writers? If they're in-house, putting their checklists in ClickUp too may simplify things.

From a usability standpoint, something I did for my team (not for briefs, but for training guides) was take everything we had in docs and put it into Google Slides presentations. It was some work for sure, but it made the presentation cleaner, less cluttered, and more user-friendly.

Hope that helps!
